Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Your letter of March 10 commenting on the cases of icterus
hemorrhagica in Guayaquil was very much appreciated. We thank you
also for sending us the copy of Doctor Rucker's letter to the Sur-
geon General transmitting cables concerning the situation in Guaya-
quil. Doctor Pareja's reply to Colonel Fisher seems is very definite.
We should receive soon further information from Doctor Pareja by
letter in reply to questions asked him by Doctor Noguchi and Mr.
Rose.
We have received the following cable from Doctor Pareja:

“Official announcement Santander, Colombia, that they
suspect yellow fever.”

We cabled at once to Doctor Miller, the Board's repre-
sentative in Colombia, asking him to make inquiry from government
and other sources and report to us. A cabled reply, somewhat mu-
tilated, has just come in, which reads as follows:

“Director hygiene does not think yellow fever Advises
asking Commission ......... board ........ Letter
with full information follows ...........”
We are asking to have the cable repeated.

This morning Doctor Roberto Franco, Presidente de la
Academia Nacional de Medicina and Profesor de Clinica de Enferme-
dades Tropicales, has been in the office. He brought a news-
paper from Barranquilla which contained items concerning the
epidemic in Bucaramanga. A copy of these clippings is enclosed.
Doctor Franco thinks that if the epidemic is not yellow fever,
it may be icterus hemorrhagica.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Florence M. Read Doctor H. R. Carter
Assistant Surgeon General
2121 California St., N.W.
Washington, D.C.
